thread.title: Loophole that could set up shock Bogut reunion

title: Loophole that could set up shock Bogut reunion
text:
Loophole in NBA CBA could see Andrew Bogut sign with the Golden State Warriors February 24, 2017 12:06pm @olgunuluc Source: FOX SPORTS WHEN it became known that Andrew Bogut was expected to become an unrestricted free agent, we were quick to rule out the Golden State Warriors as a potential landing spot. 
After Bogut was traded to the Philadelphia 76ers, all signs pointed to the two parties negotiating a buyout, which would eventually make the big-man a free agent. Because a year hasn’t past since the Warriors traded Bogut, the NBA rules seemingly dictated that the Australian wouldn’t be allowed to sign with his former team. 
However, after a review of the NBA’s Collective Bargaining Agreement, a case can be made that Bogut would technically be allowed to sign with the Warriors; if both sides possessed that desire. 
The relevant paragraph appears in the Salary Cap and Related Rules section of the CBA, under the Additional Trade Rules subheading: 
“If a team trades a player and the player is subsequently waived by the new team, the prior team will not be permitted to claim the player off of waivers or sign the player to a new contract until the earlier of (i) one year from the date the trade was completed, or (ii) the July 1 following the last season of the player’s contract (excluding any unexercised option years).” Andrew Bogut. Source: Getty Images 
The ‘loophole’ comes with the term, ‘prior team’, which is singular. This rule would seemingly apply to the Dallas Mavericks, who would be considered Bogut’s ‘prior team’. The CBA doesn’t mention any rule that states that one can’t sign with any team before that, even if it’s in the one-year period. 
It’s not known whether the NBA interprets that rule as ‘all prior teams’ within the one-year period. 
If we apply a very literalist reading to the CBA, Bogut should be allowed to sign with the Warriors; the team that traded him in order to free up space to sign Kevin Durant. 
Bogut spent four years with the Warriors, winning a championship in 2015, while helping the team to an NBA record 73 regular season wins in 2016. 
Whether there’s mutual interest between the two parties, today, remains an unknown.
